channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-8344] Improve the assignment when node failures happen to choose the secondary RS as the new primary RS
item.summary: Improve the assignment when node failures happen to choose the secondary RS as the new primary RS

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Patch that does the following:
1. Enhances the FavoredNodesLoadBalancer's methods (roundRobinAssignment and randomAssignment) to work with previously chosen favored nodes for a given region. This addresses both the case of AssignmentManager assign failures, and RegionServer failures, to assign the regions to secondary/tertiary servers.
2. Avoids the creation of RackManager for every call to the constructor of FavoredNodeAssignmentHelper.
3. Adds unit tests for (1).
Passing through hadoopqa.

I should have run 'mvn clean' after some changes I did. This patch addresses the failure.

I should add that that this patch deletes a unit test from TestRegionPlacement - the reason being two new tests that I added subsumes that one.

One more thing I forgot to mention earlier is that, the favorednodes are now stored without the startcode (set to -1). In reality, we only care about the hostname for the favorednodes stuff.

Seems ok to me.
I have a theoretical question. What's happens if we lose 2 nodes out of the ensemble of 3? Will we have the 3 region sets on the last one remaining?

What's happens if we lose 2 nodes out of the ensemble of 3? Will we have the 3 region sets on the last one remaining?

Nope. The last one will only be the current "owner" of the region and have one copy of the region files' blocks. On node failures the favored-nodes mapping is not updated (a comment is there in the code on this). The balancer, when it runs, would figure the best favored nodes for the regions. When the balancer figures the best nodes, the RegionServers in question would be made aware of the new mapping... Until the balancer runs, any RegionServer would continue to use the old favored nodes mapping for HDFS file creations and the NameNode in turn will allocate replica locations that are "close" (same rack for example) to the favored-nodes the RegionServer is passing as hints.
Fixes a bug to do with comparing of ServerName objects - makes it so that the startcode is ignored in the FavoredNodeLoadBalancer's assignment calls.

This message is automatically generated.

A couple of comments: 


+    for (Position p : Position.values()) {

+      if (favoredNodes.get(p.ordinal()).equals(server)) {

+        return p;

+      }

+    }

if favoredNodes.size < 3, you will get an out of bounds exception.

I also have some general questions not related to this patch, can do a follow up.
FavoredNodes.favoredNodesMap is a ConcurrentHashMap, but updateFavoredNodesMap() and getFavoredNodes() are also synchronized. Is this intended?

FavoredNodeAssignmentHelper.FAVORED_NODES_NUM -> should this be read from configuration default replication count for dfs? What if we are running with replication 2 or 4, we would still have 3 favored nodes?

FavoredNodeAssignmentManager.initialize() looks expensive. Do you need to call this for every roundRobin / random assignment. It seems that that info can only change if RS are going down / up.

if favoredNodes.size < 3, you will get an out of bounds exception.

In the method implementation where this code appears, there is a check just above the block of code that makes sure favoredNodes.size is equal to 3 before proceeding.

FavoredNodes.favoredNodesMap is a ConcurrentHashMap, but updateFavoredNodesMap() and getFavoredNodes() are also synchronized. Is this intended?

Yeah methods need not be synchronized as of the current code since the underlying datastructure is synchronized but in spirit I intended for the methods to be synchronized. If you feel strongly about it, I can remove the synchronized on the methods.

FavoredNodeAssignmentHelper.FAVORED_NODES_NUM -> should this be read from configuration default replication count for dfs? What if we are running with replication 2 or 4, we would still have 3 favored nodes?

This is a TODO overall. Currently, yeah, there is an assumption that the replication is 3. If the replication is 2 or 4, things should work (as opposed to crashing) and will be status quo (for example, the master will assume there is a tertiary regionserver for a region even with a replication of 2 but in reality the tertiary server is as good as any random regionserver w.r.t hosting the region's blocks).
In practice, we will mostly have a replication factor of 3 to have the failure zones taken care of and so it should be okay..

FavoredNodeAssignmentManager.initialize() looks expensive. Do you need to call this for every roundRobin / random assignment. It seems that that info can only change if RS are going down / up.

I assume you meant FavoredNodeAssignmentHelper.initialize.. Hmm.. That's how it is in the current codebase, and there are some datastructures that are valid per assignment (like uniqueRackList). Given all the other work we do in assignments (including ZK), this is probably going to be noise. But sure, I can look at this issue in a follow up..

From segregateRegions,

+      if (favoredNodes != null) {

When will the globalFavoredNodesAssignmentPlan not contain a list of favored nodes for this region? Perhaps in the case of an empty Region?

When will the globalFavoredNodesAssignmentPlan not contain a list of favored nodes for this region?

Actually, not all regions might have favored-nodes when they enter the method (FavoredNodeLoadBalancer.roundRobinAssignment). For example if the table is getting created with pre-split regions; the regions will have favored-nodes when the FavoredNodeLoadBalancer.roundRobinAssignment returns. OTOH a region could have favored-nodes when it enters the method - when we are trying to handle failure of its currently assigned regionserver.

If you feel strongly about it, I can remove the synchronized on the methods.

We can do a follow up. There should not be double synchronization.

Currently, yeah, there is an assumption that the replication is 3. If the replication is 2 or 4, things should work

As long as things do not fail out of box, this should be fine for the first cut. I was wondering if there are core assumptions in the code, which might fail in case of different default replication.

In here: 


       if (primaryHost != null) {

          continue; // we already have the region assigned to the primary; do nothing

        }

It seems that we are not adding the primary to the map assignmentMapForFavoredNodes. Is this the case?

This patch has the following updates w.r.t the previous patch:
1. Fixes the issue pointed out in the last comment (I had made an assumption about the availability of the primary RS which may not be always true).
2. Makes the testcases more tight.
3. Refactors the code a bit to move out common code into a method..

+  public static Position getFavoredServerPosition(

+      List<ServerName> favoredNodes, ServerName server) {

+    if (favoredNodes == null || server == null ||

+        favoredNodes.size() != FavoredNodeAssignmentHelper.FAVORED_NODES_NUM) {

Should the condition in the last line be:


favoredNodes.size() >= FavoredNodeAssignmentHelper.FAVORED_NODES_NUM

This way we can utilize some of the favored nodes.
Fixes the javadoc issue.

This way we can utilize some of the favored nodes.

Ted, I don't get it.. Anyway this method is just returning the position of the server in the list (after validating that it is of size 3). It doesn't do anything other than that.

+            FavoredNodes.Position position =

+                FavoredNodes.getFavoredServerPosition(favoredNodes, s);

+            if (position.equals(Position.PRIMARY)) {

+              primaryHost = serverWithLegitStartCode;

If favoredNodes.size() >= FavoredNodeAssignmentHelper.FAVORED_NODES_NUM, getFavoredServerPosition() would return null.
The if check in above snippet would become:


null.equals(Position.PRIMARY)

I think the following should be used:


+            if (Position.PRIMARY.equals(position)) {

Please don't use this construct (not that readable):


if ((serverWithLegitStartCode = availableServersContains(servers, s)) != null) {

segregateRegions() does not only seperate the regions with favorite nodes, but also assigns them. Should we rename it?

it seems the roundrobin assignment is not randomized, so if if 100 nodes, I create 3 tables all with 30 regions, they all go to the same 30 racks and RSs. We might reuse bits of DefaultLB#roundRobinAssignment(). Other strategies might be to look into loads / or keep the state from last round robin assignment, but simple randon should be fine as a first cut.

I was wondering, instead of keeping ServerName with -1 startTimes, would it be more easy to keep a HostName:Port pair around and have a hashmap of hostname:port -> List<ServerName>. Actually, we also probably do not care about port, in case multi RS run on the same server. OTOH it can get messy without ports. This is just a suggestion, please take it lightly.
Otherwise looks good.
This addresses the last few comments from Ted and Enis. (BTW I kept the ServerName for favored nodes as is, with -1 startcode; I'd like to keep it that way....)

+1 from me.

Enis offline told me that a little bit more randomization can be done in the roundRobinAssignment implementation. This patch fixes that. Also, it handles the case where some racks are smaller than the others by giving the smaller rack lesser regions during the roundRobinAssignment.
With a little more documentation.

The added comments help a naive reader, thank you!

Re: rack selection, why is the same serverID chosen on each rack? Why not choose a random server on each rack with each pass? (I presume there's some HDFS-related details with which I'm unfamiliar.)

I ran the modified tests a couple times on both hadoop-1 and hadoop-2 profiles. FYI, TestRegionPlacement consistently runs < 30sec for me on hadoop-1 (promote to SmallTest?), but times out frequently on hadoop-2.

My only other complaints are some whitespace nits.
TestFavoredNodeAssignmentHelper also runs consistently < 30secs for me on both profiles; consider promoting it to SmallTest as well?

This addresses the last comments from Enis and Nick. Makes the region assignments more balanced when racks are of uneven sizes. Also, I made the TestFavoredNodeAssignmentHelper a SmallTest as suggested by Nick. I left TestRegionPlacement as is since that spawns a MiniCluster for the tests. Explicitly disabled SSR since the test was sometimes timing out under hadoop-2 (as Nick pointed out).

I think the 2.7 patch was generated incorrectly. I see unintended changes at the top:

diff --git a/bin/hbase-daemon.sh b/bin/hbase-daemon.sh

index e45054b..034375e 100755

--- a/bin/hbase-daemon.sh

+++ b/bin/hbase-daemon.sh

@@ -1,4 +1,4 @@

-#!/usr/bin/env bash

+#!/usr/bin/env bash -x

 #

 #/**

 # * Copyright 2007 The Apache Software Foundation

diff --git a/conf/hbase-site.xml b/conf/hbase-site.xml

index c516ac7..2d0518d 100644

--- a/conf/hbase-site.xml

+++ b/conf/hbase-site.xml

@@ -21,4 +21,20 @@

  */

 -->

 <configuration>

+<property>

+  <name>hbase.cluster.distributed</name>

+  <value>true</value>

+</property>

+<property>

+ <name>hbase.rootdir</name>

+ <value>hdfs://10.11.2.132:8020/apps/hbase</value>

+</property>

+<property>

+ <name>hbase.zookeeper.quorum</name>

+ <value>10.11.2.132</value>

+</property>

+<property>

+ <name>zookeeper.session.timeout</name>

+ <value>60000</value>

+</property>

 </configuration>
Thanks for catching that Nick. This patch is the right one.
